hints_html: The tangent plane you derived in part (b) should provide a good estimate for f(x,y) for values of (x,y) near (2,1). Simply plug in the values of (x,y) into your tangent plane approximation to estimate \(z = f(x,y)\).
hints_latex:
The tangent plane you derived in
{part
(b)} should provide a good estimate for \emph{f(x,y)} for values of
\emph{(x,y)} near \emph{(2,1)}. Simply plug in the values of
\emph{(x,y)} into your tangent plane approximation to estimate
$z = f(x,y)$.
hints_raw: The tangent plane you derived in [[Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH200/December_2011/Question_01_(b)|part (b)]] should provide a good estimate for ''f(x,y)'' for values of ''(x,y)'' near ''(2,1)''. Simply plug in the values of ''(x,y)'' into your tangent plane approximation to estimate <math>z = f(x,y)</math>.
question: 1 (c)
sols_html:
From part (b), we found that the tangent plane to the surface \(z = f(x,y)\) at the point \((2,1)\) was

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle -4x + 8y - z = -1.\end{aligned}\]

Since the point \((1.99,1.01)\) is very close to \((2,1)\), the tangent plane approximation gives a good estimate for the true value of \(f(1.99,1.01)\). Plugging in \((x,y) = (1.99,1.01)\) into the tangent plane equation we get

\[\begin{aligned} -4(1.99) + 8(1.01) - z &= -1\\ -7.96 + 8.08 - z &= -1\\ 0.12 - z &= -1 \quad \rightarrow \quad z = 1.12\end{aligned}\]

Therefore,

\[\begin{aligned} {\color{blue}f(1.99,1.01) \approx 1.12}.\end{aligned}\]

estimate for the true value of $f(1.99,1.01)$. Plugging in
$(x,y) = (1.99,1.01)$ into the tangent plane equation we get

\begin{align*}
-4(1.99) + 8(1.01) - z &= -1\\
 -7.96 + 8.08 - z &= -1\\
 0.12 - z &= -1 \quad \rightarrow \quad z = 1.12
\end{align*} Therefore,

\begin{align*}
{\color{blue}f(1.99,1.01) \approx 1.12}.
\end{align*}

statement_html:
Consider the function

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f(x,y) = e^{-x^{2} + 4y^{2}}\end{aligned}\]

c) Find the tangent plane approximation to the value of \(f(1.99, 1.01)\) using the tangent plane from part (b).
statement_raw:
Consider the function
:<math>\displaystyle
f(x,y) = e^{-x^{2} + 4y^{2}}
</math>

c) Find the tangent plane approximation to the value of <math>f(1.99, 1.01)</math> using the tangent plane from [[Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH200/December_2011/Question_01_(b)|part (b)]].
